title: Sampling Bouncy Balls
question_text:
A quality control inspector in a bouncy ball plant must select a simple random sample of bouncy balls at the end of each day to make sure they are producing the required amount of bounciness.
Which of the following correctly describes a valid simple random sampling procedure?

choices.text: Place all of the bouncy balls for the day in a large container and mix them up. Draw $10\text{ bouncy balls}$ out of the container.
Place all of the solid color bouncy balls in one container and all of the swirly bouncy balls in another container. Mix the bouncy balls in each container and draw 10 bouncy balls out of each.

As the bouncy balls come off the production lines, randomly choose one of the first 50 bouncy balls
. Then choose every 50th bouncy ball
after that one until the end of the day.

Place all of the bouncy balls from production line A into a large container. Do the same for production lines B and C. Mix up the bouncy balls in each container and draw 10 bouncy balls
out of each.
All of the above describe a valid simple random sampling procedure.

solution:
A sampling method is a simple random sample only if every possible subgroup has the same chance of being chosen.

Choices 'B' and 'D' are incorrect because the bouncy balls were sorted on a characteristic (color/swirled or production line) first. This is a feature of a stratified random sample. It is not a simple random sample because a subgroup of all swirly bouncy balls has no chance of being chosen.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because the inspector is using every 50th bouncy ball
that comes off the line. This is called a systematic random sample. It is not a simple random sample because every possible subgroup does not have the same chance to be chosen.
